title: confusing covid christmas advice top
story: All the confusing Covid Christmas advice from top Tories - and what rules actually sayUK Covid rules have been changing recently - and Tory ministers claims about how to interpret them have been changing even more. Heres what the guidance says, and what MPs have added on topBoris Johnson switching on the Christmas lights in Downing Street Image: Tayfun Salci ZUMA Press Wire REX ShutterstockByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Dec | commentsYet again, you’d be forgiven for being confused about Covid rules. With the Omicron iant on the rise, the government imposed new laws on face masks and travel testing in England. But that then triggered a wave of ‘freelancing’ advice from ministers and a top official that wasn’t government policy. No has been forced to deny the Cabinet are at loggerheads amid the flurry of conflicting comments.Officially, the government’s Covid advice in England is as follows.It’s a legal requirement to wear a face maskin shops, public transport, banks and hair salons. It’s also a legal requirement for all arrivals in the UK to get a Day  PCR test and isolate until it is negative. And it’s a legal requirement to isolate for  daysyou’re a close contact of a suspected Omicron case - evenyou’re vaccinated. However, it’s not a legal requirement to cut down on gatherings or close contact, work from home, or reduce travel. Masks also aren’t a legal requirement in hospitality venues. Guidance - which is voluntary - “strongly recommends” that people wear a mask “in crowded and enclosed spaces, where you may come into contact with other people you do not normally meet.” Guidance also says people “may wish to take a rapid lateral flow test” for Covid in certain situations. These include on days when they’ll be “spending time in crowded and enclosed spaces, or before visiting people who are at higher risk of severe illnessthey get COVID-.” So with that out the way, what on earth have Tory ministers - and an advisor to the government - been saying  We take you through it.‘Don’t snog under the mistletoe, much’ Cabinet minister Therese Coffey said Brits should refrain from smooching strangers at Christmas. I donapost think there should be much snogging under the mistletoe,” the Work and Pensions Secretary told ITVaposs Robert Peston. Donapost need to do things like that. But I think we should all be trying to enjoy the Christmas ahead of us and thataposs why weaposre working so hard to get the deployment of as many vaccines as possible, and of course continuing to encourage people who havenapost been vaccinated at all yet, to come forward, recognising that weaposre still trying to understand the impact of Omicron.” Askedthere should be “just no snogging ”, she replied: Well, not with people you donapost already know! No said of Ms Coffey’s comments: “It is down to iniduals to use their personal judgement”. ‘Companies may cancel big Christmas parties’ Science Minister George Freeman turned into Mr Freelance when he appeared to contradict his own boss and No. He said: “For many small businesses, four or five staff working together every day anyway, gathering to have a drink isn’t a big step up in risk. “But some companies might normally bring hundreds of people around the world to a big party. “And they may decide this year ‘is that sensible ’, given the pandemic and given where we are.” Boris Johnson ’s official spokesman responded: “On Christmas parties, we don’t want people to cancel such events.“There is no government guidance to that end.  “It’s right that post Step Four weto the position were people can use their inidual judgement.” Meanwhile Mr Freeman said the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy would not be having a “big” festive bash. But his words came weeks after the Secretary of State Kwasi Kwarteng said a party was already booked. A Business Department source said “dferent teams do dferent things” and no single party for BEIS had been planned.‘Maybe take a lateral flow test, I might wear a mask’ Health Secretary Sajid Javid tracked close to the official guidance - but that only went to show how vague it is.He said there wasn’t “any need to change” Covid rules, but said he’d take a lateral flow test before going to a Christmas party. If you are invited to a Christmas party, thereaposs quite a few people there, maybe you want to take an LFT before you go,” he said. Go to the party, but just be cautious. Askedhe’d wear a mask at the party he replied: “Maybe. “It dependsI’m walking around or sitting down - it depends. If I’m eating. People just need to make a decision based on the guidance.” Mr Javid backed the Prime Minister, urging people to “follow the existing guidance and be sensible about that.” The Prime Ministeraposs official spokesman said: I think he was very clear about what he was saying. He was setting out that we do have a signicant testing capacity, andpeople wanted further reassurance they could use that.‘Go to nativity plays - but obviously wear a mask’Care Minister Gillian Keegan encouraged parents to attend school events - but added they should “obviously” follow non-mandatory guidance. Asked about nativity plays, she replied: “I think we’ve said go about your plans. “I mean, obviously wear a mask, be cautious, you know, all the things that people usually put in place, to be honest. “I think most people have been sensible all along, but we’re not saying to people cancel your plans and I’m sure it would be lovely to go to a nativity play right now.” AskedChristmas would be “ruined”, Ms Keegan replied: “Hopefully not”.‘Try not socialising when you don’t need to’Dr Jenny Harries is the odd one out in this list as she’s a non-political scientic advisor to the government, not a Tory minister. But the chief executive of the UK Health Security Agencytriggered the whole row earlier this week with her comments. She said working from home could be a “key” element of controlling a possible surge in future - despite No resisting the measure. She also said “not socialising when we donapost particularly need to” over Christmas could keep the virus at bay. She told the BBC : Weaposve seen that not everybody has gone back to work and Iaposd like to think of it more in a general way.Which iswe all decrease our social contacts a little bit, actually that helps to keep the iant at bay. So I think being careful, not socialising when we donapost particularly need to and particularly going and getting those booster jabs which, of course, people will now be able to have at a three-month interval from their primary course. Boris Johnson directly rejected the advice, adding: “On Christmas parties and nativity plays, we don’t want people to cancel such events.”‘We’re not in Plan B yet and don’t cancel anything’Lastly we come to Boris Johnson, who despite enacting mask laws has insisted we’re still not in his Plan B for winter. He has insisted people should not cancel anything and only need to follow the guidance. Despite saying “what Jenny’s saying there is right”, he directly rejected her advice. Askedhe agreed with her he said: “The answer is no.” The PM added: “We’re not going to change the overall guidance, we don’t think that’s necessary. We don’t see anything to suggest that we need to go for instance to Plan B, but what we do need to do is take particular precautions against Omicron until we’ve worked out exactly what kind of a threat it may present.” Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Boris JohnsonCabinetBBCConservative PartyPoliticsChristmas partyCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: labour asks civil service chief
story: Labour asks civil service chief to call in police over No  Christmas partiesAngela Rayner demanded answers over explosive claims that No  hosted social gatherings in the run up to last Christmas - while millions were living under Covid curbsBoris Johnson switches on the Downing Street Christmas lights on Wednesday Image: Andrew Parsons   No Downing StreetByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsLabouraposs deputy leader has asked the Governmentaposs top civil servant whether he will call in the politan Police to investigate the Downing Street parties row.In a letter to Simon Case, Angela Rayner demanded answers over explosive claims that No  hosted social gatherings in breach of lockdown rules in the run-up to last Christmas. Amid the fall-out of The Mirroraposs exclusive story, she asked whether the Cabinet Secretary had been aware of the gatherings that were taking place. Ms Rayner wanted to knowhe would be conducting an internal investigation into the use of Government property for the parties and the role played by Boris Johnson and his officials. The Labour deputy leader wrote: You will no doubt understand the seriousness of the allegations made. This Government is undermining public health messaging with their actions and we cannot let this go on unchecked. It cannot be that the Prime Minister believes there to be a set of rules for the public and a totally dferent set of rules for himself. Mr Johnson and his Downing Street staff have been accused of breaking Covid rules by attending parties at Number  in the run-up to last Christmas. The Prime Minister gave a speech at a packed leaving do for a top aide last November when the country was in the grip of its second lockdown. Then just days before Christmas, with London in tier  restrictions, members of his top team held their own festive bash in Downing Street. It is alleged that officials knocked back glasses of wine during a yuletide quiz and a Secret Santa while the rest of the country was forced to stay at home. The following day the PM aposcancelledapos Christmas for millions of people across the country.Mr Johnson refused three times to deny that the boozy parties had taken place when pressed at PMQs.  No  has claimed that Covid rules were followed at all times. But a Downing Street insider claimed there were often evening get-togethers while millions of people were observing the strict curbs imposed by the PM. The source said: “It was the only place you could get together and socialise. They happened most Fridays.” The Covid- Bereaved Families for Justice group slammed the PM, who faced demands to apologise for what appears to be a clear breach of his own rules. Member Safiah Ngah lost her father Zahari, , to the virus in February. The -year-old said: “Last Christmas is sadly one I will never forget. “One in  people in my borough had Covid- and my family were desperately trying to do what we could to keep each other safe. Unfortunately it wasn’t enough. To think that just a few miles away, Boris Johnson was throwing a ‘Christmas party’, with no care for the rules he had set, is sickening.“In September, he looked bereaved families in the eye and told them he had done ‘everything he could to keep their loved ones safe’. How exactly did breaking the rules himself fit into that  “While he was enjoying an illegal Christmas party, the people he should have been protecting were dying all around the country.” “The first thing the Prime Minister must do is acknowledge the hurt this has caused, and apologise.” Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Labour Partypolitan PolicePoliticsCoronavirusBoris Johnson" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: matt hancock admits blew up
story: Matt Hancock admits he blew up his entire le when he was caught kissing aideIn his first TV interview, former health secretary Matt Hancock told ITVs Peston he is "sorry to the people that I hurt" after he was caught kissing Gina Coladangelo and aide Gina Coladangelo " content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _Matt-Hancock-Gina-Coladangelo-Manchester-United-Kingdom.jpg" width"" "" Matt Hancockand aide Gina ColadangeloImage: NEIL HALL EPA-EFE REX ShutterstockByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsFormer health secretary Matt Hancock has admitted that being caught kissing an aide had blown up every part of my le as he split with his we and resigned from his government role. As images circulated of Hancockaposs romantic embrace with Gina Coladangelo last June, he said that his first thoughts were for his personal le and then his job.He told ITVaposs Peston show: As you can imagine, the first thing that I focused on was my personal le and when I focused on my professional responsibility I decided that I had to resign.Hancock was at the forefront of the governmentaposs pandemic response and had been under pressure over how it had been handled and the way contracts had been given out. Iaposd blown up every part of my le. I concentrated on my personal le first as you can probably imagine... I made the decision, he said.  It was clearly the right decision. I just say sorry again for the failure. I let a lot of people down. Iaposm sorry to the people that I hurt. He says that he is in no rush to get back to the front bench. Iaposm not in any hurry. I actually think that being on the backbenches - Iaposm enjoying it, he continued.Itaposs a very important job. I think contributions from people who have been there in the heat of battle... Theresa May, the contribution she makes as a former Prime Minister. If I can make that sort of contribution...Hancock denied that he was directly involved with the giving out of a £ million contract to a company in his constituency when he was health secretary. Iaposve absolutely no idea because I didnapost have anything at all to do with that contract, he told the ITV programme. And more importantly, the gentleman in question and his company didnapost get a contract with the department or the NHS. They were a subcontractor and therefore they didnapost have a contractual arrangement with the department... I have been told, through the media and outlets, that somehow there has been some great scandal here, and itaposs just not true.I had nothing to do with this contract, and there isnapost a contract between my constituent and the department. He was a subcontractor. But more importantly, at that time, do you remember what it was like  We were doing everything we possibly could to save lives and all this stuff about contracts, which has all been looked into by the National Audit Office, it is all just - actually what happened behind the scenes is people worked incredibly hard to do everything they possibly could to save lives. The UK was slow off the mark in testing people for Covid but now have high percentages compared to other European countries and Hancock believes this is the way to go. We should test the hell out of ourselves, he said. The best way to keep yourself safeyouaposre seeing people - knowing I was coming to see you, I took a test this morning - we should test the hell out of ourselves and that is the best way to just be really cautious and careful. Get those tests - theyaposre available free - and take them and that will help to keep things open. title: our society wont help through
story: Our me-me-me society wont help us get through the coronavirus pandemicYou see selfish behaviour everywhere, and its at every level, from iniduals to whole countries during the coronavirus pandemic, says Polly HudsonBoris Johnson has left everyone scratching their heads lately Image: POOL AFP via Getty ImagesopinionByPolly Hudson:,  Nov | comments I regretted it immediately. We were at the theatre, to see a show my son had been learning about at school, a super special early Christmas treat.Behind us were five women in their thirties who, from the off, talked, and not even in stage ­whispers only during the big musical numbers. They chatted at the top of their voices throughout, as though they were at home in front of the telly rather than surrounded by people, and being incredibly rude to the performers on stage a few feet away. Half-way through the second act, I snapped. Although that makes it sound much more impressive than it was, because obviously I just meekly and incredibly Britishly pleaded with them to be quiet. Please. Thank you. Sorry. It did not go well. I was stupid for trying. What did I think they were going to say, “We had no idea we were disturbing you, please accept our apologies ”  Of course not. They knew they were being loud. They didn’t care. It reminded me of whenever I’ve seen anybody ask someone to wear a mask. The last time, it ended with the personanswering the polite, reasonable request with, “You f***king bitch, mind your own business”.The irony of saying that about a global pandemic – by definition, everyone’s business – seemingly lost here.Now there’s a potentially serious new iant, so we’re being asked to do something. The something that a worldwide study found to be the single most effective public health measure at tackling Covid. Wear a mask.  The reaction to this small ask, and my uncomfortable theatre experience, has left me with a depressing realisation. We’re not living in a Me First society. We’re living in a Me Me Me Me First society. This was impossible to ignore thanks to the amount of maskless people going about their business on Monday – in shops, on public transport , everywhere. They knew the mandate was coming into effect the following day, and why, but still they refused to take part in the communal effort to save Christmas – and, you know, lives – until there was no other option. Admittedly the messaging has been insane over the last few months. There will be some who think you must not need to wear a maskthe man with the most important job in the UK doesn’t. With so much changing so quickly, keep on top of what is happening with the Mirroraposs news updates by email. Delivered straight to your inbox, our daily coronavirus briefing will keep you informed of what is happening with Covid, lockdown, the vaccination rollout and the impact on how we live.here. But there are others who know this isn’t the case, but don’t want to wear masks, so they just… don’t. Similar to the kind of person who feels like chatting loudly in a theatre, so just… does. Apart from no one diespeople talk in a theatre. The truth is that there are a lot of utterly selfish iniduals out there. We see it on a larger scale with rich countries not doing enough to supply vaccines to poorer ones because they’re too worried about themselves. And what gets lost is that helping them is the best thing we can dowe’re worried about ourselves, becauseeveryone’s vaccinated, spread is reduced and iants less likely to develop. We all need to look out for each other, with masks, with sharing vaccines, with compassion. Only then is there hope for us all. title: pfizer boss backs vaccinating 5
story: Pfizer boss backs vaccinating -year-olds as UK watchdog prepares official adviceDr Albert Bourla said "there is no doubt in my mind that the benefits, completely, are in favour" of the Covid vaccine for under-s as the JCVI looks at whether to approve the jabs in the UKA child receives the COVID- vaccine in Tel Aviv, Israel Image: Xinhua REX ShutterstockByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Dec | commentsPressure to decidefive-year-olds should get Covid vaccines has risen after they were backed by the boss of Pfizer. The pharmaceutical giant’s chief executive Dr Albert Bourla said the virus is “thriving” in schools and “there is no doubt in my mind that the benefits, completely, are in favour of doing it”. It comes as the UK’s vaccine watchdog prepares official advice on whether to offer jabs to kids aged  to . Currently those aged  and over are offered it. The Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisationsaid this week: “No vaccine is currently authorised in the UK for use in children aged  to  years. “JCVI will continue to review data on the potential benefits and risks of vaccination of children aged  to  years and will issue separate advice in due course.” JCVI member Prof Adam Finn warned the “balance” of whether to vaccinate kids was “still quite uncertain”. He told BBC Breakfast the main benefit of immunising children is the indirect protection of adults.He added: The extent to which we can do that and protect adults by avoiding them being infected by children with the current vaccines is still quite uncertain. So, thataposs the balance - we clearly want to protect children as much as possible and weaposve got good evidence now that this vaccine, even at a low dose, produces a really good protective immune response in children and produces many fewer side effects because of the lower dose. The question really is that should that be our focus right now. “Or should we really be focusing on adults who are the ones that much more commonly get seriously ill.  The United States Food and Drug Administration has approved the Pfizer jab for younger children. The boss of Pfizer said immunising that age group in the UK and Europe would be a good idea. Covid in schools is thriving, he said. This is disturbing, signicantly, the educational system, and there are kids that will have severe symptoms.” No said it would wait for the scientists to make a recommendation. It comes as Brits look set to get a fourth dose of the Covid vaccine after the UK signed deals for  million additional jab doses lasting up to .Health Secretary Sajid Javid has confirmed deals for extra doses of Pfizer and Moderna have been accelerated in light of fears over the new Omicron iant.The new deals for  and  include access to modied vaccinesexisting jabs are found to be less effective against the worrying new strain. That appears to suggest Brits could be offered a fourth dose, given the supply would be more than enough to do so. It is not yet clear whether the vaccines will need to be tweaked every year for new iants, as happens with the annual flu jab. Pfizer boss Dr Bourla said he believed Covid vaccination will become an annual event. news politics top-tory-blasts-macrons-panto-"Macron slammed for ‘pantomime’ comments about JohnsonByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | comments A top Tory has slammed Emmanuel Macron’s “unhelpful pantomime” jibe at Boris Johnson - as he insisted: “Of course the Prime Minister isn’t a clown”. Minister George Freeman weighed in after the French President privately hit out at the straw-haired Prime Minster and his “Johnson circus”. According to the magazine Le Canard Enchaine, Mr Macron claimed his counterpart had “the attitude of a vulgarian”. He said: “BoJo talks to me at full speed, everything is going fine, we have discussions like big people, and then he gives us a hard time before or afterwards in an inelegant way. “It’s always the same circus.” Mr Macron is reported to have added: “It is sad to see a major country with which we could do huge numbers of things, led by a clown.”  Science minister Mr Freeman told Sky News: “I think we’re into pantomime season aren’t we, and there’s a French election coming. “It’s a pretty unhelpful word. “Of course the Prime Minister isn’t a clown, he’s the elected Prime Minister of this country with a very big mandate, leading this country through the pandemic.” He insisted: “I’m confident Anglo-French relations are better than that quote suggests.” Downing Street has not commented on the comments, which have not been officially confirmed by the Elysee Palace. But last night a UK government source suggested things will only improve after the French Presidential election in April - which could oust Mr Macron. The source said: The Prime Minister continues to be a staunch advocate for the strength of the UK-French relationship.“Our approach will not change, evenwe have to wait until the other side of the French Presidential election for a change of tone.”Relations between London and Paris have been in the deep freezefor months over post-Brexitfishing rightsand Channel crossings. The situation worsened after Mr Johnson published onTwittera letter he had written to the French leader, demanding action to crackdown on illegal Channel crossings.On Wednesday night a Cabinet minister said she was surprised and disappointed at reports of the French President’s words.Work and Pensions Secretary Therese Coffey told ITV ’s Peston: “I’m surprised to hear that. “I’m conscious that we have a shared mission in trying to make sure that the people smuggling gangs are really brought to justice.” When it was put to her that the development was troubling, Ms Coffey added: As I say, Iaposm surprised to hear that and disappointed, openly. Iaposm sure that we can continue to try and work together to tackle this. “But the Prime Minister wrote to the President last week and... I hope that weaposll get a formal response back. People smugglers, they donapost carepeople live or die. They just want their money. And weaposve got to try and work this through, not only between our two shores, but actually tackling this in the first place. And Iaposve got confidence that Priti [Patel] is trying to make those inroads right across not just Europe, but also in our more international communications as well. title: uk pre departure travel covid
story: UK pre-departure travel Covid tests couldby Christmas as No wont rule outLabour has led calls for pre-travel tests toto battle the spread of the Omicron iantAll internationals arrivals are required to take a PCR test and isolate until they get their result Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political Editor:,  Dec | comments Passengers could be asked to take pre-departure Covid tests before Christmas amid growing pressure on ministers to tighten up travel rules. Downing Street did not rule out bringing back pre-travel tests before the end of the year as the Government monitors the spread of the new Omicron iant. Boris Johnson has announced a package of new Covid measures to buy time for scientists who are racing to understand the threat of the new strain.Since am on Tuesday, all internationals arrivals are required to take a PCR test and isolate until they get their result. But a leaked paper from the Governmentaposs SAGE advisors said pre-departure tests would be valuable, adding that the current plan would identy signicantly fewer cases thanpeople were asked to take tests on day  or .  Askedpre-departure tests were on the agenda, Science Minister George Freeman told the Today programme: Weaposre looking at all the data and Omicron is, weaposre literally live work every day on looking at the data, both internationally and domestically. He added: We are watching the data very closely and we will update the guidance as required. Asked to rule out bringing in pre-departure tests before Christmas, the Prime Ministeraposs official spokesman said: “I think what I can say is at the moment we have this three week review point… we believe restrictions we’ve put in place … strike the right balance between protecting lives and livelihoods. There are no plans to introduce pre-departure tests, we think the Day  test is the right way.  The spokesman added: It’s not a restriction we’re planning to introduce based on what we currently know.But Shadow Home Secretary Yvette Cooper said: It is totally unacceptable that ministers are failing to take action at the border when even their own advisors are telling them to introduce pre-departure tests.“It cannot be right that people can travel to an airport, board a busy flight, queue at busy departure gates, and travel on trains and buses in the UK, all without having taken a test. “The government must not repeat the mistakes it made earlier in the pandemic by being too slow to take action to prevent further cases of the Omicron iant entering the UK.” The Scottish and Welsh Governments have issued a joint call for ato tests on day  after people arrive back in the UK. title: girl 6 rare skin condition
story: Girl, , with rare skin condition that makes her shed becomes child modelGorgeous Harper Foy, six, has fulfilled her dream of becoming a child model after being scouted by an agency - and after years of worry from her parents, shes made tons of friends at schoolHarper has started school and landed a modelling contract Image: PA Real LeByRikki LoftusJessica TaylorReal Le Features Writer:,  Dec | commentsA little girl whose skin sheds like a snake and has put her in intensive care has landed her first modelling job. Adorable Harper Foy, six, has harlequin ichthyosis , which makes her skin grow  times faster than normal - meaning she has to have four showers every day to soothe it. The schoolgirl from Washington is thought to be one of only  people in the USA living with her condition - and for the first few years of her le, her parents were worried she wouldnapost ever go to school at all. However, Harperaposs mum Angie, , said so far, her brave daughter hasnapost let the condition hold her back. “There are other people with her condition that we’re aware of who are home schooled, so the fact that Harper has been able to start kindergarten this September is a miracle for us.”For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here Harlequin ichthyosis causes the skin to grow  times faster than normal, making it thick, dry and severely scaly. At birth, it requires intensive care. One of the only things that can soothe her angry skin is a shower - so Harper has to spend around four hours under the water every single day. Since starting her first year of school this autumn, Harper has had to have an hour long shower before heading into class. Then at lunchtime, sheaposs picked up for a pitstop to have a second shower.When she gets home from school, she has her third shower of the day, before a final shower at bedtime.Angie said: “The showers are an inconvenience, but they are essential for Harper to be able to go about her day.  “Because her skin sheds so much, it becomes itchy and sore, so the showers alleviate a lot of that discomfort. Angie and her husband Kevin, , were concerned their daughteraposs condition might stop her making friends at school because she has to come home at lunchtime. But luckily, their outgoing daughter hasnapost let anything stop her. She said: “She has lots of friends at school and they are all very conscious of her condition and help hershe needs it. “Kids are so resilient, and Harper is no dferent.”Although things are likely to get more complicated with Harperaposs schooling as she gets older, Angie hopes her daughter will be able to stay in school up to her teenage years.Angie, who lives with her husband, Kevin, , a project manager, and their three children, Harper, Sam, , and Jaxon, , said: I’m not sure how it’s going to work as Harper gets older, she said.The schoolwork will naturally get more dficult, so it will be harder for her to miss things tohome for a shower.“But we will figure that out when we reach that point. With her attitude, I’m sure Harper will achieve anything she puts her mind to.”Itaposs been a big year for Harper, who lives with her parents and brothers Jaxon and Sam.Sheaposs been scouted as a child model after charming an agency with her sharp sense of humour. Her mum gushed: You can’t help but love her when you meet her. Sheaposs got this unmatched personality, this sense of fun.“She was signed up to a two-year contract with a modelling agency just before the pandemic but, unfortunately, that meant there weren’t any jobs coming in.“Now that the world is starting toto normal, she’s just shot her first modelling campaign.Although Angie has to remain tight-lipped about the nature of her daughteraposs campaign, she hopes Harper will be able to see her face on billboards one day. Due to Harper’s condition, she did not have her hair and make-up done like models usually do, but Angie says she still felt very much part of things on the day of the shoot.“Her skin and scalp are too sensitive to get her hair and make-up done, but they had music blasting and Harper was dancing around the room, said Angie. “She loves Ed Sheeran, so they were playing his music for her too. Harper loves dancing and music. I always say she is an old soul.“The commercial will come out early next year and she is so excited about seeing herself in it.”Angie says her daughter has come a long way since she was born, and is now thriving. She said: “The early days were spent doing a lot of research on her condition and hearing dferent things from doctors on what course of treatment they were going to offer next.  “It was a very scary and uncertain time for us and now, to be out the other side, feels like a dream.“Harper will always be dferent from other people and her skin will always need special care and attention, but we will cross each bridge as we get to it.“I used to worry a lot about how the world would treat a girl like Harper, with her condition. Do you have a real le story to share  Email jessica.taylor@reachplc As her mother, I still worry sometimes, but I also have no doubt that she will take the world by storm.“She’s a beautul girl inside and out and she deserves a full le of fun and happiness.”Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON EducationLoveParenting" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: bar doorman asked is angela
story: Bar doorman frequently asked is Angela in tonight explains how he helps womenThe code phrase is part of the Ask Angela campaign aimed at helping women who feel unsafe, vulnerable or threatened in bars, clubs and other night time venues" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _Security-guard-are-regulating-the-situation-of-safety-in-an-event-concert-in-a-nightclub.jpg" width"" "" Anyone who feels vulnerable can approach bar or security staffImage: Getty Images iStockphotoByCharlotte HadfieldDanya BazaraaSenior News Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsA doorman who has been asked is Angela in tonight on multiple occasions has explained how he helps women in need. The code phrase is part of the Ask Angela campaign aimed at helping people who feel unsafe, vulnerable or threatened in bars, clubs and other night time venues, Liverpool Echo reports. Anyone who feels this way, can approach bar or security staff using the special code word Angela, which indicates to staff that they require help or support.This might be in the form of calling them a taxi, reuniting them with a friend or calling security and or the police. Adam Potter has been asked the question several times since he started his job as doorman in Liverpool city centre five months ago. The -year-old said every night at work he is approached by women who ask him to keep an eye on men who are making them feel uncomfortable on the dancefloor. And when Adam has been asked by women is Angela in tonight , he says he has stepped in to help.  Adam told the Liverpool Echo: They basically say aposcan you keep an eye on this guy heaposs making me feel uncomfortable apos I probably get that at least once a night, possibly three or four times a night - thataposs just girls who come up to me. They might say aposheaposs tapped me on the bottomapos, in which case he gets thrown out. Any touching inappropriately they get thrown out immediately. Adam has spoken out in the hope of raising awareness of the Ask Angela campaign and encouraging other bar staff to learn about the initiative. It comes after a post was shared widely on social media about the importance of the campaign in keeping people safe on nights out. Adam said: What happens is,a girl comes up to you and says aposIs Angela in tonight apos you know exactly what she means. What you then do is say aposyes apossheaposs in tonight just come with me.apos You take her behind the bar into the staff area and phone for a taxi. In more extreme cases, bar staff might have to call the police or security. Adam said: I went into this job basically just to help people and I do my very best but when I hear about girls constantly being harassed and not being as safe as they used to be going out it makes me feel upset. title: ba worker who sacked after
story: BA worker who was sacked after having tumour operation wins £, payoutCordelle Scotland, , had to take time off following an operation and bosses told her to swap her shts - a tribunal ruled she had been treated unfavourably by British AirwaysA tribunal ruled British Airways treated Cordelle Scotland unfavourably Image: REUTERSByNeil ShawAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Dec | commentsA British Airways worker who was sacked after having a tumour operation has won a £, payout from the airline. Cordelle Scotland, , had to take time off following an operation to treat her endometriosis and was told by her boss to try and swap her shts. Cordelle, who worked at Heathrow Airport as a customer services representative, complained after failing her probationary period and was told she had been sacked as she had been late to work several times. A tribunal ruled the airline treated her unfavourably by criticising Cordelle for not swapping shts. The airline was ordered she be paid £, compensation for injury to her feelings.  Cordelle suffered from fibroids and endometriosis, which causes excessive bleeding, a hearing was told. Having worked for BA for eight months and had her probationary period extended due to concern over absences and lateness, she told bosses she needed to undergo surgery for the condition. The tribunal heard Cordelle sent an email in November  explaining: I am due for hospital admission on th December for an abdominal myomectomy due to my fibroids and endometriosis reaching the stage of disability which in turn affects my work and le in general greatly.To put it into perspective, my uterus is the same size as a five and a half month pregnancy due to the tumours.The recovery period is about  weeks however I have concerns as to how this may affect my probation. I need to have this surgery on this date as I have been having treatment for the last three months to help shrink the fibroids before surgery and it is not recommended for me to continue the treatment any longer than three months as it has induced me into menopause which can trigger osteoporosis. My third and last treatment will be on the th November. As a result, she was signed off by her GP for two weeks from December . When her probationary period ended in February , Cordelle was told her employment would be terminated as your attendance level is unacceptable and you have been late to work on  separate occasions between March  and February . In an email, Heathrow Services Manager Nicola Drinkwater added: I have taken into account that you had a planned medical procedure on the th December , which you have been recovering from and signed off work by your GP between th December  - nd February .  However the seasonal roster you were working offers vast amounts of flexibility to swap shts and work on available rest days prior or post your procedure. She also cited a further three occasions of lateness which came after a review meeting in October  that extended Cordelleaposs probationary period due to concerns regarding your attendance and performance. Cordelle then emailed CEO Alex Cruz and Tom Stevens, BAaposs Head of Worldwide Airports, and said she made all attempts to ensure my surgery would not interfere with my employment. She added: For Nikki to then make the statement that I should have sorted my recovery time off with sht swaps and leave is completely unfair and discriminatory. for our daily newsletter to keep up to date with all the essential information atwww.mirror email.My surgery was gynaecological for endometriosisand uterine fibroids . Why should I be expected to have covered recovery time from major surgery with leave and sht swap. Ms Drinkwater told the tribunal Cordelle was sacked for the high number of times she was late and that it was not because of her sickness absence nor the need to be on restricted duties following herto work. Cordelleaposs claims for wrongful dismissal, direct discrimination because of race and or sex and or disability were dismissed by the tribunal. It also ruled that BA failed to make reasonable adjustments for her disability. The tribunal further ruled that BA had treated her unfavourably under the Equality Act by considering her absence for the operation when terminating her contract and in criticising her for not swapping shts. In his ruling, Employment Judge Oliver Hyams stated: Ms Drinkwater plainly did take into account in making her decision the fact that [Miss Scotland] had had some absences from work on account of sickness which was the result of having endometriosis, which [BA] accepted was a disability. Ms Drinkwater did that by criticising [Miss Scotland] for not swapping shts with the result that she did not, as far as Ms Drinkwater was concerned, exhibit what Ms Drinkwater would have regarded as a commendable spirit. That treatment of [Miss Scotland], ie that criticism, was made only as a result of her being unable to work because of the surgery which had been required to mitigate the effects of her disability. The tribunal said Cordelle would have been sacked anyway because of her lateness but awarded her compensation for injury to feelings. title: boy 15 sets up scotch
story: Boy, , sets up scotch egg business in lockdown - now says his dreams have come trueSchoolboy Oliver Jackson has cracked the key to success after taking over the once failing business Jawbone Scotch Egg Co from a family friend last year - and he isnt planning on stopping thereOliver Jackson found himself with some extra time of his hands - so got down to business Image: MEN MediaByAmber OConnorSam Elliott-Gibbs:,  Dec | commentsA young entrepreneur has made his dreams come true thanks to the launch of his lockdown scotch egg business. Hardworking schoolboy Oliver Jackson put his extra time to good use to get his tasty new-look enterprise off the ground.The -year-old took over the running of Jawbone Scotch Egg Co during lockdown last year after the one-time owner called it a day, Yorkshire Live report.Now the Sheffield ladaposs big idea is growing and growing - and he has set his sights on giving football fans their fill. The British favourite became a major talking point a year ago when the government introduce a apossubstantial mealapos rule for bars and pubs to allow them to open. Those in the hospitality industry demanded to knowa Scotch Egg qualied - and it finally got the thumbs up.  Now locals have given their taste approval and Oliver has big plans for the venture. He now sells upwards of one hundred scotch eggs from his small shop in Oughtibridge, Yorkshire, every Saturday. And after giving up his evenings and finding the aposhardapos balance between running the business while staying in school, Oliver appears to have cracked the key to success. His next goal is opening a shop near Sheffield Wednesdayaposs Hillsborough stadium to sell to hungry football fans on match days. Oliver said: All Iaposm thinking is how can I make it bigger. When I realised I could go for it myself it was a dream come true. Jawbone Scotch Egg Co now supplies four local cafes as well as selling from a converted shipping container on his familyaposs Greenhead House Farm. Flavours include Punjabi Curry, full English, and Port and Cranberry during the festive season. The boy plans to expand at his base, too.He hopes to add seating and will buy a coffee machine to attract even more customers.The products are handmade each week using locally sourced meat and eggs. title: couple transform boring rental gorgeous
story: Couple transform boring beige home into luxury hotel and find Instagram fameOnce they moved in to the £, property, Alicia began experimenting with dferent colours and decoration options to make everything their own original styleCouple transform boring rental into gorgeous luxury hotel home Image: Emerald TerraceByAbigail Nicholson:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsA couple have transformed a former rental home with beige walls and light floors into a gorgeous home described as a aposluxury hotelapos. Alicia Murphy, , and her husband, Guy, moved into their home in West Derby, Liverpool, in September  with their rescue dog, Otis, after thinking the property ladder was out of reach for them.It wasnapost until the pair spoke to a mortgage adviser that they realised they could be eligible for a % deposit option, Liverpool Echo reported.Alicia, who is from Liverpool originally said: I loved that it had character in the form of period features, I loved the location and it was pretty much a clean slate decor wise, which meant we could put our own spin on it. I think it had been a rental property before the owner decided to sell it on, so it was very much beige walls, light floors, etc. The couple paid just under £, for the home with a £, deposit and said their monthly cost of living was around £ including their mortgage and bills. Once they moved in to the property Alicia began experimenting with dferent colours and decoration options to make everything their own aposoriginal styleapos. But the -year-old admitted she didnapost have an initial vision for the property. She said: Originally we’d only planned to paint the walls green and have a green sofa, and it wasn’t until we moved in and I started experimenting with decorating, colour schemes and interior styles that I realised I totally loved everything ‘maximalist’ and quirky. Social media has been amazing for providing inspiration and ideas. Instagram is one of the main s I use - not only can you see other people’s amazing homes and styling, but you can also follow along with tutorials and DIYs and actually try them out for yourself. I also use Pinterest a lot.Six months after moving into the Liverpool home, Alicia set up her own blog and Instagram account to keep people updated with her progress and to share ideas with others.The Emerald Terrace Instagram now has .k followers.Alicia said: I’d wanted to start a blog for years and just wasn’t sure what my niche could be. To tell you the truth, I was never too interested in interiors before moving into this house. I set up the account about six months after moving in - a few people said I should try it because my home was that little bit dferent, and it just grew from there really! Hundreds of people comment on the Emerald Terrace Instagram updates to ask Alicia questions and compliment her home. One commenter said: You’ve NAILED the luxury hotel bathroom vibe. Another added: Forever wishing I could copy and paste your perfect perfect home for myself! Looking ahead, the couple said they expect to move on in the future but can see themselves living in West Derby for a few more years yet. The -year-old said: I think we’ll definitely move on in the future as it’d be great to have some more space, but that won’t be for a few years now. I’ve already had people jokingly tell me they’ll be the first to buy itI ever come to sell! news uk-news detective-says-dad-stepmum-who-"Arthur Labinjo-Hughes cries no-one loves me in harrowing audioByMartin Fricker:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec Tragic Arthur Labinjo-Hughes would still be alivethe Covid- lockdown had not happened, detectives believe. The six-year-old was living with his paternal grandparents, who “loved and cherished him”, when the pandemic hit. But his dad Thomas Hughes decided to move in with girlfriend Emma Tustin when the country was plunged into lockdown.Today his evil stepmum convicted of murdering the defenceless child after a horric campaign of abuse, while his dad was found guilty of manslaughter.Det Insp Laura Harrison, of West Midlands Police, said it “was the worst decision that could have been made”. “If only Hughes had left Arthur with his grandparents who absolutely doted on him, loved him and cherished him,” she told the Mirror. “The manipulation and the toxic relationship between Tustin and Hughes meant the family were cut out of Arthur’s le and didnapost play a part. “The lockdown meant professionals didn’t have the opportunity to monitor him in the same way they would do with children normally. “I do think that lockdown contributed. “The professionals who would ordinarily have been involved in Arthur’s le, such as teachers, weren’t having that contact with him and spotting changes in his behaviour or bruises on his body. “Tustin and Hughes cut off family members so Arthur was no longer seeing or speaking to him. “And when social workers went out to Tustin’s home there was an absolute manipulation of them by the defendants. “It was the only day when Arthur was allowed to play in the garden and he presented very dferently as a result. “When the professionals did speak to him they weren’t picking up on the signs they would have donehe had been segregated in a hallway. “Tustin and Hughes pulled the wood over the eyes of the professionals. They didn’t want children’s services involved.” Specialist grief counsellors were drafted in to help police left traumatised by Arthur’s death. Veteran detectives were left in tears as they watched CCTV footage of the helpless youngster alone in his family home. They also discovered harrowing evidence that Arthur had been sadistically poisoned with salt by his dad and step-mum. DI Harrison described it as the “most traumatic” case she had ever investigated.  She compared his death to the murder of Daniel Pelka, the tragic four-year-old boy killed by his mum and step-dad in . In both cases the children were deliberately poisoned with salt to increase the suffering before their deaths. “I knew when we started it was a horric case, but there have been moments that have just completely got me,” she said. “Everyone involved has found it really haunting having to witness and experience the evil and horric torture that Arthur was subjected to. “There are real similarities with Daniel Pelka, definitely in terms of salt poisoning. “I’d not heard of it before in child cruelty cases and it’s been really hard to comprehend. But it is a haunting parallel. “A physical assault is one thing - but it’s very devious and manipulative to dose a child up with salt. It’s another level of evil. “It could only have been done as another way to control Arthur - an extra punishment. “We think maybe they did it to make him more thirsty but we don’t know because they’ve never given us an explanation.  “It’s been really dficult for the officers who have to sit for hours watching CCTV footage of Arthur being isolated. “I arranged for a trauma counsellor to come in to explain the emotions people might be experiencing and to teach coping mechanisms they could put in place. “They have been able to independently see the counsellor without the rest of the team knowing. “We don’t ordinarily get faced with CCTV like this. “The footage really got to the heart of what Arthur was being subjected to and thataposs why it’s been so hard-hitting and dferent to similar cases. “When you add in the  recordings of Arthur in distress and the brutal text messages, it sets it apart from the Pelka and Baby P cases. “We’ve been reliant on medical expert opinion and it’s been crucial. “But the actual emotional element of this case has been proved by that CCTV or hearing audio clips where he is calling out for family members, calling out for food or water, and that nobody loves him. “We all know children in our lives. You just cannot comprehend anybody being able to neglect a child over such a sustained period of time. “It was not a sudden loss of control, it was a well thought-out campaign of abuse, both physically and psychologically, towards Arthur.” DI Harrison said it was “hard to comprehend” how Hughes and Tustin tried to blame Arthur for his fatal injuries. She said: “They’ve blamed each other and they’ve blamed Arthur as well. “How can a six-year-old boy be responsible for what happened  We know he couldn’t have inflicted his fatal injuries himself. “They are both equally responsible. Although Tustin killed Arthur, Hughes encouraged the killing by actions.” Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON West Midlands PoliceCCTVCCTV footageCrimeMurderPolice" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: families home schooling sick kids
story: Families home schooling sick kids to protect them face prosecution in bonkers ruleGetting back to normal has left millions of clinically vulnerable people behind but, rather than recognising the dilemma faced by vulnerable families, Education Secretary Nadhim Zahawi has doubled down on the Tory Government’s position, Toby, and Phobe,  pictured at their home in Whitchurch, Bristol. The children are currently not in school due to concerns over covid and Toby’s type  diabetes condition." content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _RGP_MDM_Morris_.jpg" width"" "" The Morris family in Somerset - Charlie Morris with children Finley,  , Toby, and Phoebe,  at their home in Whitchurch, Bristol Image: Rowan Grfiths   Daily MirrorByRos Wynne JonesReal Britain columnistClaire Donnelly:,  Dec | commentsSarah Brooks has chronic ­rheumatoid arthritis. Like many people on immunosuppressant drugs, she is double-vaccinated but hasn’t developed any ­antibodies to Covid-. Her four-year-old daughter, Ella, has a rare type of epilepsy that can be ­triggered by a virus or a fever. With Covid rates rising, and the new Omicron iant gaining ground, Mrs Brooks has taken the decision to home school her three children. But – under current government rules – now faces being fined. “We were invited for a meeting with the attendance officer and were told we face fines and or prosecution,” says Mrs Brooks . “On the same day we got a letter saying that the school itself was at the centre of a Covid outbreak. It’s bonkers.” The family have now got in touch with the Good Law Project, who have sent a pre-action letter to the local council challenging the decision to enforce attendance. Getting “back to normal” has left millions of clinically vulnerable people behind. At one time .million were official “shielders”. One in four of them have never stopped according to ONS figures. Now they are just people who can’t go out, but have no extra support. Last week, the number of pupils absent from school in England because of Covid rose by about %. Some , state-school pupils were absent with confirmed or suspected cases on November .  Rather than recognising the dilemma faced by vulnerable families, the Secretary of State for Education, Nadhim Zahawi, has doubled down on the Government’s position with a letter to school leaders about “maximising” school attendance. “We are at a crucial point in the pandemic and must collectively act now to ensure lower levels of attendance do not become the accepted norm,” the letter says. “I hope you agree on the urgency.” For the Morris family in Somerset, the letter was devastating. Toby Morris, aged , has had Type  Diabetes since he was a baby. His sister, Phoebe, seven, is a brittle diabetic who needs round-the-clock monitoring. “Because the Government is saying no one has to shield and children should attend as normal, we’re stuck in this nightmare,” their dad Charlie,, explains. “The bubbles, isolating, all the things schools were doing to keep children safe, it’s all gone out of the window. “There are thousands of families like ours put in a position where schools are saying they can’t authorise any absence because it’s meant to now be attendance as normal – but because there are vulnerable people in our family that isn’t safe for us. “School is important – I’m a former teacher. But an education is no goodyou’re dead or suffering a chronic illness as a result of a nasty infection. Our son’s already suffered enough living with a le-long, le-limiting condition.”The family are also being supported by the Good Law Project after they say their local MP, Jacob Rees-Mogg, failed to reply to them.This week, the Government ­introduced masks into communal areas in schools, but stopped short of further mitigations like increasing ventilation, classroom bubbles, masks in classrooms and further access to vaccinations for children. Many Year  children won’t turn  until long after winter. Even then, the vaccination programme for children is grindingly slow. Nadhim Zahawi recently met with Miriam Cates, a Tory MP and education committee member who believes “Covid isn’t a risk to children”. Andrew Lewer MP tweeted “Miriam Cates MP  I met with @nadhimzahawi about face masks in schools  our aspiration to phase them out.” Cates is well-known for her ­opposition to mask wearing because “showing our faces is part of being human”. She has also called for an end to the regular testing of schoolchildren without symptoms, and says there is “no rush” for vaccines in schools. For Ella Brooks, at home in the Midlands, catching Covid could be a death sentence. Her rare form of epilepsy means she suffers intense seizures particularly when she has a fever. These can start in her sleep and cause her to stop breathing. “Once again we are behind Wales and Scotland in terms of mitigations being adopted, despite Covid currently running rampant through most schools in England,” her mum says. “The message seems to be ‘attendance at all costs’ – but for us, that cost could be someone’s le.” A Department for Education spokesperson said: “The best place for young people is in the classroom, it is vital for their education and mental health which is a priority. “All children should be supported to continue to attend school and our guidance to schools about attendance of clinically vulnerable children has been clear throughout. In line with guidance every child aged  and over with specic underlying health conditions has been offered the vaccine.” No one wants ato lockdown home schooling. And yet failing to use masks alongside mitigations like ventilation will likely end in soaring cases. Yesterday, Gwynedd in North Wales, announced ato online learning after a spike in cases. More councils may soon be following suit. “There’s this  argument that you’re pro-freedom or pro-lockdown but it’s not that simple,” Sarah Morris says. “We don’t want lockdown and we want schools to stay open, but we need them to be made safer and at the moment, for families like ours, they’re not. As parents it’s really stressful.” For her the choice comes down to one thing. “I’ve sat at my daughter’s bedside, watched her struggling. Her condition can be le-threatening and I have to do what I can to prevent that.” Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Tory GovernmentJacob Rees-MoggNadhim ZahawiEducationSchoolsMental healthArthritisPoliticsEpilepsyCoronavirusCoronavirus lockdown" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: first aston martin db6 vantage
story: First Aston Martin DB Vantage restored to glory after  years languishing in garageAston Martin DB Vantage is now worth £, after being put in storage in  and forgotten about until  when it was bought by classic car enthusiast John CookThe restored car is worth £, Image: Max Willcock BNPSByJoseph Draper:,  Dec | commentsThe first Aston Martin DB Vantage ever made has been restored to its former glory after it spent  years languishing in a garage. The incredibly rare time capsule, that is now worth £,, was the first to leave the production line in September . The show car toured for , miles across the country and was used by the carmakers to advertise their state-of-the-art creation. But after its star-studded first years, the Aston passed into private hands and was put in storage in  where it was left to fall apart. The Vantage was forgotten about until  when it was bought by classic car enthusiast John Cook at an auction.  He spent a whopping £, on an extensive restoration project, ing the car to its factory condition with Fiesta red paintwork and black leather interior. It even includes original copies of magazine reviews, its parts catalogue, instruction book, owner logbook, and test certicates. Charles Ramsey, owner of Classic Connection in Burley, Hants, where the car has ben consigned for sale, said it was the ‘rarest DB in existence’.  He said: “The most impressive thing about this car is that it was the first DB Vantage - and only the third DB - ever to leave the production line. “It was used as a factory demonstration for advertisements and magazine reviews making it very rare to a collector. “The car has been fully restored to its original Fiesta red and all its specications compared to others of its kind which were often changed.  “The history file includes magazine reviews of the car, its owner logbook, instruction book, and factory build sheets. “It’s a blessing this piece of Aston Martin history was discovered after lying dormant and restored to such a remarkable degree”. Mr Cook handed the motor over to Aston Services Dorset, the officially-appointed restorers of vintage Astons, for the restoration project. Only , DBs were made at the Aston Martin factory in Newport Pagnell, Bucks, between  and . The Vantage iant came out in  but only  models were made. The Vantages, which offered a more powerful performance, were even more exclusive. They had a .-litre straight six-cylinder engine that could deliver bhp compared bhp that standard DBs had. Mr Cook, , who is also from Burley, said: “Cars from this period often got to the stage where their value dropped and owners forgot about them which seems to have been the case with this one. “When I bought it, it was in a serious state of disrepair and I gave it to Aston Services Dorset to undergo a £, restoration. “It is such a special car which is so perfect and I want to give it to someone  to enjoy. “I’ve got another project in mind so I needed to clear the decks to get myself ready for it. “I have a real passion for finding old things and bringing them back to how they originally were.” Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Aston MartinCars" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news graphics-show-mutated-omicron-iant-"Omicron: Health minister says Christmas will hopefully not be ruinedByDave BurkeSenior News Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | comments Worrying graphics show just how mutated the newly-emerged Omicron iant is - as scientists around the world scramble to find outvaccines work against it. Illustrations released by the Genomics UK Consortiumshow that it has a worrying  mutations on its spike protein. By comparison Delta - which tore through the population last winter and has since become the worldaposs dominant strain - has seven. Experts have said Omicron, which was first identied by scientists in South Africa, is the most mutated Covid iant they have yet encountered. This morning a spokesman for the UK Health Security Agency told The Mirror that targeted testing is being carried out for the iant.  This means that not every positive PCR test is screened for the new strain.At the weekend Boris Johnson announced a range of measures aimed at halting Omicronaposs spread, including compulsory PCR testing for all travellers arriving in the UK from abroad.  Contacts of those identied as having the strain are also required to isolate for  days, regardless of whether they have vaccinated. Officials say it is too early to tell how worried we should be about the iant, with Brits urged to show caution.  The strain has been classied as of concern by the World Health Organisation . It is feared that Omicron could prove resistant to vaccines because of the number of mutations in its spike protein. This affects how it responds to antibodies in the immune system, and the way it enters human cells. This week South African Raquel Viana, Head of Science at one of South Africaaposs biggest private testing labs, said she had a sinking feeling when she discovered the new strain while genetically testing positive swabs in the country.  She told Reuters: I was quite shocked at what I was seeing. I questioned whether something had gone wrong in the process.Early indications show most Omicroncoronavirus cases are mild, the World Health Organisation has said. The official believes there is no evidence to suggest the efficacy of vaccines reduces when battling against the new iant.The organisation, quoted by Reuters, suggested most cases so far examined are not severe. They cautiously added there is still a lot not yet known about the new strain. title: how having mould house affects
story: How having mould in the house affects your health - and how to get rid of it safelyMould and damp can be dangerous, especially for the more vulnerable members of your household - learn how to to tackle the problem that affects % of all homes in the UKAround  per cent of British homes suffer with damp and far more with mould Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByHarry ThompsonSEO Writer:,  Dec | comments Having a cosy, warm place to go in winter is vital - but musky carpets, a brown stain on the ceiling and condensation on the windows as a draft whistles through the house can put an end to it very quickly. However a damp cold home is not only extremely unpleasant, it can also be very bad for your health. Government data has found that in the two years to March , % of all homes in the UK had damp in one room or more while between % and % are thought to have black mould.Damp and mould appear when there is excess moisture in the home, which can be caused by anything from leaking pipes and rising damp on ground floors to leaking ceilings and poor ventilation. How does mould in the house affect my health  Damp in the home can have a array of negative health effects, causing respiratory infections, asthma and allergies. It produces a number of substances that disagree with the human body, including irritants, allergens and, on occasion, toxic substances. If you inhale or touch mould it can lead to allergic reactions including sneezing, a runny nose, skin rashes and red eyes. In more severe cases it can directly lead to asthma attacks. It affects some worse than others with babies, children, the elderly all more sensitive to it.It can also affect people with pre-existing medical conditions that are made worse by its presence. They include people with skin conditions like eczema, respiratory problems like asthma and allergies or those with a weakened immune system like someone undergoing chemotherapy.How to safely get rid of mould from your homeAccording to homeserve, getting rid of mould on walls can be achieved using a number of dferent chemicals including baking soda, white distilled vinegar or % concentration of hydrogen peroxide. They should be applied to the area and left for a time before being scrubbed.It is crucial you find you where the excess moisture is coming from - once you know the source you can begin to take steps to mitigate the effects or solve the issue completely. Getting this done may sometimes need professional help, although smaller amounts can be done yourself. If your home is newly built yet still damp it could be that the water used in its construction, like in wall plaster, is still drying out. How do you stop mould growing in your home  Homeserve suggest a number of top tips for preventing mould from taking hold, they say: Open windows every day to let fresh air in and moisture out Close the door of the room you’re ventilating to keep the rest of the house warm and prevent moisture escaping to other parts Open a window or use an extractor fan when showering, cooking or using a tumble dryer When you’re not showering or cooking, leave internal doors open to let air flow freely around your house Dry any washing outside when possible If you do dry washing inside, open a window and close the door of the room it’s hanging in If you have window vents, leave them open permanently Use a dehumidier and moisture traps on windowsills to remove damp from the air Dry any condensation from windows and windowsills Clear out roof gutters regularly to avoid water overflowing onto your walls Check roof tiles and fascia boards and repair any leaks or rotting wood Check that your damp-proof course is above the ground level of your home Fix plumbing leaks quickly and dry the area. title: i grew up petrified aids
story: I grew up petried of Aids - the stigma from the s pandemic is still reAs we mark World Aids Day, I remember the crippling terror and shame I felt about being a gay teenager with no informed knowledge of HIV, writes Liam GilliverIn the s Aids was seen as a stark death sentence, a self-inflicted consequence of a dirty lestyle a decade of tragedy Image: Getty Images iStockphotoopinionByLiam GilliverOpinion Writer:,  Dec | commentsIn a pre-Covid world, most people in their twenties were lucky to have no anxiety around their health. Weaposre free to party, toke the occasional cig, sleep with whoever we want to, and nurse our hangovers with fast food and sleep. But for many young gay men, including myself, the fear surrounding HIV and Aids can be crippling - evenweaposre not exposing ourselves to potential infection. In the aposs, the Aids crisis, also known as the aposgay plagueapos, had the world in a panicked chokehold. It was seen as a stark death sentence, a self-inflicted consequence of a dirty lestyle a decade of tragedy. And while medical understanding has advanced by leaps and bounds - the stigma surrounding the virus still echoed on to younger generations.I was six years old when Section  was finally abolished in England and Wales. The notorious law, brought in during Thatcheraposs administration, prohibited schools from talking about homosexuality. But a decade later, at the ripe old age of , I still hadnapost received any form of LGBTQ+ sex education at secondary school or sixth form. I didnapost know that HIV was no longer the death sentence that it once was, or what aposundetectableapos meant, or why as a teen who hadnapost even had sex I was so afraid of it. Because I really was petried at times.  At school, youaposd regularly hear jokes about people being bummed and getting Aids - but no teacher attempted to correct the ignorance or debunk the myths. And for some reason, I couldnapost talk to anyone about my constant panic of dying - because the stigma surrounding the virus is still re, and education is still so poor.  In fact, according to sexual health charity Terrence Higgins Trust, the most recent estimate suggests there were , people living with HIV in the UK in . Of these, around , are undiagnosed and do not know they are HIV positive. Equally alarming,  percent of people living with HIV have never shared their status with anyone outside of their healthcare workers. Now, my experience with health anxiety is nothing compared to the thousands of people living with HIV who face discrimination on a daily basis. But it highlights how strong the reverberations of the aposs crisis are - and how important it is we begin to educate children about HIV. Today is World Aids Day - but headlines surrounding Covid continue to dominate. Perhaps because Aids is still seen as a gay comeuppance that doesnapost really affect the straight world - or maybe because the stigma is so ingrained into our society itaposs impossible to smash. But we must break through. If not, history could easily repeat itself.HIV is the name of a virus. Aids is the name for a collection of illnesses caused by this virus. HIV stands for Human Immunodeficiency Virus. ‘Immunodeficiency’ refers to the weakening of the immune system by the virus. HIV has been passed on between humans for many decades but was only identied in the early s.AIDS stands for Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome. It is a collection of illnessescaused by a virus people pick upthat makes their immune system weak . You can’t get an AIDS diagnosis unless you’re already HIV positive. In the s and early s, most people with HIV were eventually diagnosed with AIDS. Now, thanks to modern antiretroviral treatment, very few people in the UK develop serious HIV-related illnesses. The term Aids isn’t used much by UK doctors. Instead they talk about late-stage or advanced HIV. If left untreated, infection with HIV progresses through a series of stages: from flu-like seroconversion illness, through infections associated with the symptomatic stage, leading to late-stage HIV or AIDS. If someone with HIV has a detectable viral load, they can pass on HIV through blood, semen, vaginal fluid, anal mucus and breast milk. HIV is not passed on by spitting, sneezing or coughing, nor by kissing or general social contact. HIV can’t survive for very long once itaposs outside the human body. Studies have shown that a person whoaposs on effective treatment who has an undetectable viral load canapost pass on HIV. For more information, visit the Terrence Higgins Trust.Most ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON World Aids DayPrince HarrySex educationHIV and Aids" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you.
