title: afghanistan rally around starving children catherine deveney opinion
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. title: coronavirus in scotland track the spread in these charts and maps
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. title: i look back with pride and a smile swimmer hannah miley retires
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. title: athletics megan keith aiming high in european cross country championships
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. title: aberdeens chris leiper handed back to back psa outings in december
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. title: red star stung late in exciting league match
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.RJD-sponsored Red Star welcomed Baljaffray to the Joint Campus G pitch last Saturday where the sides played out a thrilling three-all draw in a match which swung in either direction in horrendous conditions.The sides exchanged goals in the first half, with Stuart MacLean reacting quickest in the box after the Baljaffray keeper couldn’t hold a Fraser Talbot shot and the striker scored to net his eleventh goal in eight games.Baljaffray forced a succession of corners near the end of the half and were on level terms when Red Star were only able to partially clear a corner which fell to the away side’s full back and his shot via the aid of a deflection went past young Leon Murphy in the Star goal. -Into the second half and Star could have retaken the lead when Aaron Moore latched onto a drilled cross from strike partner Stuart MacLean, however, his effort was blocked by an excellent save from the Baljaffray number one.The visitors took the lead after  minutes when a cross caused confusion in the Star defence and the Baljaffray forward had the simple task of finishing into an empty net from close range.Star huffed and puffed for an equaliser, however, they were frustrated by excellent goalkeeping until the goal came in fortuitous circumstances after a long ball was nodded past his own keeper by the Baljaffray centre back meaning the sides were level with  minutes to go.Star took the lead with five minutes remaining when Aaron Moore was able to burst clear of the Baljaffray backline and finish well into the far corner to make it -.This should have been enough to see Star over the line but Baljaffray scrambled a late equaliser when Star again failed to clear a free kick and the ball was bundled over the line to see the match end -.Lochgilphead Red Star are on their travels on Saturday November  when they face their toughest test of the season so far as they take on league leaders and title favourites Arthurlie.

title: battling star hold title favourites
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Red Star ed home with a point after a battling performance against league leaders and title favourites Arthurlie on Saturday November .Star stung the hosts at Cowan Park, Barrhead, with an excellent start to the match, forcing a succession of corners before the ever-dangerous Coll McCallum finished after an excellent delivery by Craig Aitken.The visitors doubled their lead after  minutes when Craig Aitken broke clear down the left and finished with an excellent effort into the goalkeeper’s far corner to put Star - ahead.Star were under pressure for much of the remainder of the half but always carried a threat on the break, with Stuart MacLean’s pace causing the home side no end of problems.Into the second half, Arthurlie forced their way back into the match and pulled a goal back after a rare defensive lapse by Star on  minutes. Star failed to clear the danger from a cross and the unfortunate Coll McCallum erted into his own net past Leon Murphy.The Arthurlie equaliser arrived with  minutes remaining when winger Sean Ross cut inside before unleashing a spectacular effort into the top corner.The hosts would have been expected to go on and win the game from here but the Star defence remained well-organised and resolute and a fine goalkeeping performance from Leon Murphy ensured the Lochgilphead side ed home with a well-earned point.Star put their unbeaten league record on the line on Saturday November  when they welcome fellow Argyll side Cardross to the Joint Campus G. title: argyllshire advertiser leader column november 19 2021
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Maybe it is a sign that the young folk causing damage at Blarbuie Woodland are maturing, but it was good to hear that some, at least, had gone back to help clean up their mess.Whatever their motivation, good on them.The night-time antics there over quite a period have been pointless, infantile and regularly dangerous. And do these kids# families not know where they are in the evenings The carrot of working with ACT, the police and wider community to create something positive is on offer for young people.But so too is the stick, eventhis is something that most would rather avoid using.Let#s hope they continue to grow out of getting kicks from damaging things which folk have put their heart and souls into creating for others.Last year#s Remembrance was strange in the pandemic.Maybe we felt the need this year to reconnect with tradition, or perhaps the past  months has offered a little insight into the infinitely more arduous trials faced by those we remembered last Sunday.The fact that so many people came out on a cold day was heart-warming.

title: galas-chance-put-town-football-map
story: ARGUABLY Gala Fairydean Roversrsquo biggest game of the season takes place on Saturday when League Two Annan Athletic visit Netherdale in the third round of the Scottish Cup.The winners will go into Monday nightrsquos draw along with the giants of Scottish football ndash and potentially a huge pay day could be the reward.Manager Neil Hastings is not underestimating the challenge ahead and is urging fans to create a good atmosphere and cheer the team onto victory.He told the Border : ldquoSaturday will be a huge challenge against a team who perform at a higher level."Itrsquos the biggest competition we play in, and we have the chance to reach the fourth round. Crowds have been improving recently and Irsquom hoping to see the local community turn out in their numbers for this chance to put the town on the football map. I know the players will relish a good atmosphere.The pair met last Boxing Day in the same competition and the visitors took the honours with a late goal and Hastings knows the task ahead.Hastings added: ldquoAs a manager I never stop thinking about the next game but Irsquove seen Annan a few times and had reports. I know it will be dficult as they have some good inidual players. We played them last year and since then they have added quality and depth to their squad. Theyrsquove been playing well and will be looking to get into the play-offs for promotion and are well-placed.Tickets cost pound  pound ndash pay at the gate. Us pound.

title: see-live-rugby-region-weekend
story: A FULL-CARD of live rugby s to the region and beyond this weekend.On Saturdayin the Premiership Hawick host GHA, Selkirk are away at Musselburgh whilst Jed-Forest are at home to Edinburgh Accies.In the Tennents National League Division One Gala travel to Stirling to face the Wolves, Kelso host Cartha Queenrsquos Park at Poynder Park whilst Melrose are in the capital to face Heriotrsquos Blues.In the Tennents National League Division Two Peebles are away at Whitecraigs.In the Tennents National League Division Three Berwick are away to Greenock Wanderers.In East League One Duns are away to Linlithgow.In East League Two Hawick Linden face Corstorphine in Edinburgh.In East league Three Gala YM host Earlston in a Borders derby.In the Reserve East One Hawick Force host Biggar, Jed-Forest A are at home to Edinburgh accies and Selkirk A are away to Musselburgh A.In the Reserve League East Two, Gala A host Leith A, Melrose Storm are at home to Edinburgh Accies B, Peebles Reds host Watsonians B and Kelso Sharks are away to Linlithgow A,In the Semi-Junior Borders League Hawick Youth host Gala Wanderers, Kelso Harlequins are at home to Carlisle Colts, Melrose Wasps hosts Morpeth Colts and Peebles Colts are at home to Alnwick.On Sunday Kelso Ladies play Stewartry at Poynder Park.As always games are subject to late change so always check before going along.

title: mccallum-hoping-world-title-eliminator-vegas
story: Galashiels boxer John McCallumrsquos IBF Intercontinental Cruiserweight title fight against Kazakhstan fighter Issa Akberbayev at York Hall was postponed at the last minute.The fight had been scheduled for Friday  November but Akberbayev withdrew citing illness two days before.A previous fight between the pair was called off by Akberbayev due to Covid.A frantic search to find another opponent for the McCallum failed and he is now in talks about a world title eliminator in Las Vegas next month.A disappointed McCallum told the Border : ldquoThat fight was for meant to be for my dad Steven Robinson who is seriously ill with cancer in Edinburghrsquos Western General Hospital and that has been taken away.ldquoI had a massive support and many of them were spending the weekend in London.ldquoIrsquom really annoyed and it has even made me think of chucking it. The whole thing has been a massive disappointment. It wasnrsquot about belts or money it was for my dad and as soon as I found out I drove to Edinburgh to be with him.ldquoI donrsquot think Irsquoll be fighting Akberbayev again after the two call offs. This was an oral virus which meant he was unable to fly.ldquoIrsquove been asked to fight Andrew Tabiti who is in the Mayweather camp for a world title eliminator which would take place in Las Vegas on -December at the Mandalay Bay and Irsquom up for that. The Intercontinental belt is still vacant butthis comes off Irsquoll bypass that.ldquoI peaked for the Akberbayev so Irsquoll have a few days rest then get back in training at my local gym before heading to Vegas about five days before the fight. Irsquom in good shape so that should be OK.

title: date-announced-next-years-maroond-gala-festival
story: BUILDING on its success in , the Maroonrsquod@Gala sports and music festival willto Netherdale next year.The event will take place at the home of Gala Rugby, on Saturday, August , .Praised for its innovation and inclusivity, the inaugural edition of Maroonrsquod@Gala provided competition opportunities for primary school age rugby players under s under s under s senior and ladies sections and players with physical and learning disabilities.It also played host to football and running events.In addition to the showpiece sporting event ndash which culminated with the final of the famous Gala Sevens - there were live bands, street food, themed drinks areas and fun zones.Despite challenging weather conditions and the requirement to work in accordance with government coronavirus guidance, the free  event was attended by around ,-, people.It received positive feedback with participants, vendors and spectators stating their intention tofor future editions.Ian Dalgleish, the president of Gala RFC, said: ldquoThe Maroonrsquod@Gala concept has been very well received and the success of our inaugural event this summer, coupled with positive feedback and the continued support of our partners, has given us confidence to bring it back in .ldquoTogether, wersquore committed to creating a community event that local people want to be part of and to celebrate the proud sporting history of Gala Rugby, as well as to inspire our future stars."We also want to build on what we achieved this year and to extend the feel-good factor beyond the Netherdale site, maximising the positive economic impact in Galashiels town centre.Maroonrsquod@Gala was initially scheduled to take place in April  but was postponed due to the coronavirus pandemic.Further details will be announced in due course.

title: scotland-women-head-dubai-february-cup-qualifiers
story: THE WOMENS edition of the Rugby World Cup  Final Qualication Tournament will take place on  and  February  at The Sevens Stadium in Dubai.Scotland will compete alongside Samoa, Colombia and the winner of the Hong Kong v Kazakhstan playoff for the last remaining place at Rugby World Cup  in New Zealand, now due to take place between  Octoberndash November, .The Final Qualication Tournament will operate in a semi-final, final format over two match days.This is the first time the womenrsquos edition of Rugby World Cup has featured a Final Qualication Tournament offering teams a second pathway to qualy for RWC  with the winner booking their place in Pool A alongside hosts New Zealand, Australia and Wales next year.Eleven teams have already booked their place at Rugby World Cup , including New Zealand, England, France, Canada, USA, Australia and Wales, who qualied through their final ranking at Ireland , and South Africa, Fiji, Italy and Japan who qualied through their regions.Rugby World Cup  Tournament Director, Alison Hughes, said: ldquoWe are pleased to be able to share the details of the Rugby World Cup  Final Qualication Tournament. A first for a womenrsquos edition of a Rugby World Cup the tournament offers teams a second opportunity to qualy for the pinnacle event and we anticipate a thrilling contest between competing teams in Dubai in February.Tom Burwell, The Sevens Stadium General Manager, said, ldquoWe are hugely excited to host world-class womenrsquos XVs rugby at The Sevens Stadium. It will be the first time such a competition has taken place in the UAE. With the Emirates Dubai s ing over the next two weekends, itrsquos an exciting time for rugby in the region. We are honoured to be working with World Rugby once more in delivering international rugby. With the winner going onto New Zealand and RWC , we are excited to be part of a nationrsquos journey to the very top of the womenrsquos game..removeThe RWC  Final Qualication Tournament will be live streamed across World Rugby and RWC  digital and social s.Rugby World Cup  will be the showpiece event in womenrsquos rugby union s, with the first tickets for Rugby World Cup  selling out in minutes. Tournament organisers are calling on fans to secure their tickets early to avoid disappointment.

title: christmas-classic-coming-borders-next-month
story: FOLKSY Theatre are heading back to the Borders, bringing the classic story of The Little Match Girl to le in this brand new, musical adaptation.An upbeat, festive adaptation of the Christmas Classic. The Little Match Girl wanders the street on Christmas Eve, trying to sell her match sticks. Everyone is busy celebrating with fires, Christmas trees and delicious food but outside the girl is cold, sad and alone, that is until she lights one of her matches to keep warm and visions come to le before her very eyes!Join the Little Match Girl on a magical journey, filled with live music, puppetry and multimedia. This is a family Christmas show not to be missed!This production uses a mix of live performers, puppetry, live music and multimedia and brings and happy twist to this much-loved text. With high-energy performances, audience interaction and out right silliness, Folksyrsquos The Little Match Girl will be a theatre experience to be remembered.Tom Hardwicke - Director said: lsquoWe had a lot of fun adapting this beautul tale. It was important to us that we kept the message and morals of the story, whilst making it happier and more uplting. It has been a joy to bring it to le, with our talented actor musicians. Itrsquos a really fun, family show and wersquore delighted to be back working with Live Borders this ChristmasrsquoJason Moyes ndash Senior Creative Programming Officer at Live Borders said: lsquoFolkyrsquos Theatre delight audiences wherever they go, and itrsquos a pleasure to have them performing at the Corn Exchange. The way they work with puppets is quite spectacular and the cast really bring stories to le, itrsquos a perfect show for the whole family.rsquoAimed at children aged - but suitable for all ages. Date: Friday  December  Venue: Corn Exchange, Melrose Doors: : Performance: : Price: pound Duration: hr

title: nicola-sturgeon-covid-update-today---omicron-variant-new-rules-considered
story: Nicola Sturgeon held an emergency Covid briefing today as the first cases of the Omicron iant were identied in Scotland.The first minister was joined by Scotlands chief medical officer Dr Gregor Smith to detail what they currently know about the situation in Scotland.The new Omicron iant, which was first discovered in South Africa, has led to countries around the world tightening restrictions amid concerns it could be more transmissible than the Delta iant.UK prime minister Boris Johnson announced tighter measures on mask wearing and travel over the weekend for England, reintroducing mandatory face coveringsin shops and on public transport.Meanwhile, in Scotland, face coverings have been compulsory in these settings throughout the majority of the pandemic as highlighted yesterday by the first minister on the Andrew Marr Show.As the Omicron iant continues to dominate headlines, heres what we learned from Nicola Sturgeons Covid update today....  Omicron cases detected so far in ScotlandSome of the  cases currently detected have no link to travel to or from South Africa, which suggests there could be some level to community transmission.. "Signicantly" increase compliance with current rulesThe Scottish government is asking people to signicantly increase compliance with the current rules in place: wearing face coverings, taking regular lateral flow tests, getting vaccinated and maintaining high levels of hygiene.. No evidence currently to suggest disease caused by Omicron is more severeAccording to the WHO, there is currently no evidence to suggest that illness caused by the Omicron iant is more severe.However, the first minister said this remained under review. Situation in Scotland stableAlthough the first minister couldnt provide a detailed updated on the figures in Scotland, which will be published later today, she confirmed that the current situation in Scotland was stable..remove. Travel restrictions could be tightenedNicola Sturgeon has written a joint letter with Welsh leader Mark Drakeford to the UK government urging a four nations policy to introduce an -day self-isolation period for people arriving from overseas.The first minister said:"We are proposing a tougher four-nations approach to travel restrictions at this stage that would see people arriving in the UK from overseas asked to self-isolate for eight days. In our proposal, they would take a PCR test on day eight of their arrival, as well as on day ."Currently  countries are on the red list andanyone arriving in Scotland from anywhere outside the common travel area, will be asked to take a PCR Covid test on the second day of their arrival, and self-isolate until they get the result of that test back.. Further actions will be considered in coming daysFurther actions regarding rules and regulations to curb the spread of Covid will be considered in the coming days as we learn more about the Omicron iant. Hope remains that concern surrounding this iant can be reduced as we learn moreThe first minister said that she remained hopeful that as we learn more about this Covid iant, concern surrounding it will reduce rather than increase.

title: borders-drop-in-centres-offer-hot-food-without-power
story: DROP-IN centres will open across the Borders for residents without power in need of hot food, it has been announced.Scottish Borders Councilsays around , homes in the region have been affectedafter Storm Arwen hit the UK over the weekend.And now the council is opening centres at ldquokey locations to provide free soup, meals and hot drinks.The drop-in centres will run at:Duns Primary School ndash am to .pmSt Ronanrsquos Primary School, Innerleithen ndash .am to pmHawick High School ndash .am to pmEarlston Primary School ndash .am to pmAnyone who is unable to travel to the schools should call   to request assistance.An SBC spokesperson said: ldquoThousands of homes have remained without power overnight, mainly across rural Berwickshire, and the council continues to liaise closely with Scottish Power Energy Networks and other key partners across the region to ensure support is available to those affected.ldquoAnyone with welfare concerns or who has been unable to find alternative accommodation should call   so that appropriate assistance can be provided by the Council or partners.ldquoResilient Community groups have continued to support the councilrsquos response, including through providing rolling checks on vulnerable residents in communities affected by power outages.ldquoPlease note that only Scottish Power Energy Networks can provide updates on when power may be restored.

title: local-man-named-community-path-volunteer-year
story: A BORDERS man has been recognised for his dedication to developing and maintaining walking paths in Earlston, contributing to improving the health of many in his local community.Ian Gibb, who co-founded the Earlston Paths Group was named winner of Community Path Volunteer of the Year at Paths for Allrsquos Volunteer Awards  at a virtual awards ceremony hosted by BBC Radio Scotlandrsquos Fiona Stalker.Since retiring from Royal Mail in , he has been working to develop and then keep the path routes in Earlston in top form ensuring they are accessible for locals and visitors to enjoy.He said: ldquoI have always enjoyed walking and when I retired it was important that I kept myself busy. Thatrsquos why in , I decided to form the group along with my co-founder Jack, who is sadly no longer with us, to develop existing and new walking routes in the area.ldquoThere is plenty of banter when we go out to work on the paths and it gives us a chance to meet new people like contractors, the Paths for All team, local walkers and people visiting the area itrsquos great to build new relationships with these people and hear their story.ldquoThe group is made up of ten volunteers, each contributing in their own way. As well as that, when we have larger projects on the go we are fortunate that more people in the community come out and help.ldquoThe community has really taken ownership of the paths too,anything happens like broken steps, handrails, bridges or even a fallen tree, they know Irsquom the one to call.The charity supports local authorities and communities to develop inclusive environments for people to be active whether walking, cycling or wheeling.Kevin Lafferty, Chief Executive Office at Paths for All, said: ldquoIniduals like Ian highlight the very reason why we host an annual awards ceremony. It is vital that we celebrate and shed light on the outstanding work that volunteers carry out in local communities across Scotland on a daily basis..removeldquoOur volunteerrsquos invaluable contribution is directly working to improve the nationrsquos physical, mental and social health which has been evident throughout the pandemic, with many going above and beyond their normal duties.ldquoHearing the inspirational stories during the award ceremony has highlighted that it is not just enough to say thank you ndash the work undertaken has provided a le line for many and for that wersquore forever grateful.To find out more which Health Walks you can join in the Scottish Borders, visit: www.pathsforall.org.uk healthwalkfinder

title: 78-year-old-man-completes-final-fundraiser-charity
story: A -year-old Bordersrsquo man who walked almost , miles during lockdown to raise money for Cancer Research UK has finally called time on his fundraising activities after raising an impressive pound, for Cancer Research UK in memory of many of his friends who have died from the disease since the start of the pandemic.David Laing from Kelso had  falls, luckily none too serious resulting in only a few head stitches, cuts and abrasions during his travels and the wrong footwear resulted in the loss of his left foot big toe nail which still causes him pain but is starting to grow back.He was soaked many times, battered by hailstones, snow and sleet and heavy winds and had to replace four pairs of trainers but on the brighter side he has taken more than  photos of wildflowers and have named almost all, photographed some beautul scenery, river and farm le, shed a few pounds and lted litter which he have done for almost  years.He is an inspirational figure in the community who is also a telephone kindness volunteer with the Chest Heart and Stroke Association and still collates PVGs for Scottish Borders Disability Sport Group.David told the Border : ldquoOn the th November  the fund was closed after just over three months having raised the maximum amount of pound which has now all been paid over to CRUK either directly from the link or on a week to week banking arrangement.ldquoWhat a fabulous amount so thanks to all donor and supporters This is my final ever major fundraiser which I can imagine will be a huge relief to many who became lsquototally voluntaryrsquo donors without any pressure .

title: michael-buble-visit-borders-2022-summer-tour
story: GRAMMY Award-winning singer Michael Bubleacute is set to visit the Borders next year as part of his UK summer tour.Bubleacute will perform at Floors Castle in Kelso on Monday, July , .An Evening with Michael Bubleacute will see the Canadian singer tour picturesque locations across the UK for the series of open-air events.The four-time Grammy Award winner has sold more than  million records worldwide and recently released a music video for Its Beginning to Look a Lot Like Christmasahead of the th anniversary of his festive album, Christmas.Following his show in Kelso, Bubleacute will go on to perform in Durham, Bath, Cardf and Exeter.Tickets for the event at Floors Castle will go on sale on Fridayand are available at: www.aegpresents events detail michael-bubleTickets for all other dates in July  are available now.You might also be interested in:Man, , diesafter getting into dficulty in River TweedSP Energy Networks issues updateas homes still without power after Storm ArwenConcerns raised over ongoing issuesat Borders site used by travellers

title: souters-appear-holiday-alley-web-tv
story: NINE Scottish country dancers from Selkirk have appeared on a lsquoWorldwide Dancing in the Street Videorsquo that aired on Holiday Alley web-TV today As part of the Holiday Alley Festival held in the town of Selkirk Manitoba, Canada, residents of towns named Selkirk from around the world were invited to film themselves dancing.The Souters, who are all aged over  took up the challenge and their dance to the -bar reel lsquoDeil Amang the Tailorsrsquo impressed the judges.Margaret Pritchard told the Border : ldquoWe are all from the Selkirk Scottish Country Dance class and have been dancing together for a long time. We got permission to film our dance in front of the Mungo Park Court which was appropriate as itrsquos just across from the statue of Mungo Park.ldquoThe dance was filmed and sent away to the festival organisers and we just received an email back saying that they were delighted with it so we are all thrilled and looking forward to watching it later this month.The women who took part were Maureen Buckley, Shirley Brown, Freda Nicholson, Margaret Pritchard, Mary Harkness, Maureen Davidson, Olive Stillie, Wendy Boustead and Ros Roxburgh.

title: power-issue-sees-borders-high-school-pupils-sent-home
story: PUPILS at a Borders high school have been sent home due to a ldquopower issue, according to the council.The local authority issued an update on the issues in the region after Storm Arwen hit the UK on the weekend.The council says that all schools ing from holiday today reopened as normal with the exception of Berwickshire High School, where a power issue has resulted in pupils being sent home.Inspections will continue today at settings in the Eyemouth and Earlston clusters to ensure they are ready for theof pupils and staff tomorrow, according to a council spokesperson.:Man, , dies after getting into dficulty in River TweedMeanwhile, Scottish Borders Council is running a drop-in centre for those still without power at Duns Primary School.The facility will be available until pm tonight .On the situation in the region, the spokesperson said: ldquoWhile supplies have been restored to a number of homes across the region, there are still those without power, mainly across rural Berwickshire.ldquoThe council continues to liaise closely with Scottish Power Energy Networks and other key partners to progress the recovery effort.ldquoAnyone who is in need of assistance should contact    up to pm.
